review.title: New Perspectives in Sinographic Language Processing Through the Use of Character Structure
review.abstract: Chinese characters have a complex and hierarchical graphical structure carrying both semantic and phonetic information. We use this structure to enhance the text model and obtain better results in standard NLP operations. First of all, to tackle the problem of graphical variation we define allographic classes of characters. Next, the relation of inclusion of a subcharacter in a characters, provides us with a directed graph of allographic classes. We provide this graph with two weights: semanticity (semantic relation between subcharacter and character) and phoneticity (phonetic relation) and calculate "most semantic subcharacter paths" for each character. Finally, adding the information contained in these paths to unigrams we claim to increase the efficiency of text mining methods. We evaluate our method on a text classification task on two corpora (Chinese and Japanese) of a total of 18 million characters and get an improvement of 3% on an already high baseline of 89.6% precision, obtained by a linear SVM classifier. Other possible applications and perspectives of the system are discussed.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The Chinese script is mainly used in the Chinese and Japanese languages. Chinese characters (or "sinographs") are notorious for their large number (more than 84 thousand were encoded in Unicode [1]) and their complexity (they can have from one stroke as they are to 64 strokes as they are;). Despite their complexity, the Chinese script is quite efficient, as semantic and phonetic information is stored in bar patterns that can be easily recognized by native readers. In this essay, we will deal with a certain type of bar pattern, namely those that also exist as distinct characters - we call them subsigns. We will examine the phonetic similarity (called phonetics) and the semantic relationship (called semantics) between a character and its signatures. After building a graph of sign inclusions, and attaching various types of information to it, we will introduce an improved NLP task model: together with individual characters, we will use graphical data that is included in their subline structure.

sections.heading: 1.1 Related Work
sections.text: Various attempts have been made to describe sinographs in a systematic way: [2] and [3] use generative grammars, [4] use a prologue-like language, [5] use the biological metaphor of gene theory, [6] describe sinographs as objects with properties (the chaon model), [7] define a formal language type called planar regular language, [8] and [9] describe the topology of sinographs in XML, [10] use projections of percussion boxes, and [11] use combinatories of IDS operators. [1] The OCR community has also shown a strong interest in the structure of sinographs [12]. Concerning the consideration of Chinese writing as a network, this has been done in several papers, such as [13, 14] (where edges represent components combined in the same sinograph) or [15], where components and sinographs form sequences.

sections.heading: 2 Definitions

sections.heading: 2.1 Strokes
sections.text: A sinograph consists of a number of strokes, which are arranged according to certain patterns within an (imaginary) square. Strokes can be assigned to 36 calligraphic line classes. The latter were encoded in Unicode (table cjk Strokes). Furthermore, strokes are always drawn in a very specific order. [1] Ideographic description sequences do not describe sinographs per se, but provide operators with a basis for finding the graphical combination of existing sinographs in groups of two or three. IDS operators can be arbitrarily nested and were encoded in Unicode (tabular ideographic descriptions).

sections.heading: 2.2 Components, Subcharacters, Radicals
sections.text: Similar to etymological roots in Western languages, readers of sinographs recognize stroke patterns, so that the meaning of an unknown sinograph can be more or less effectively identified by the stroke patterns contained therein. Frequently occurring stroke patterns are referred to as components. In this essay, we are dealing only with components that also exist as isolated sinographs. Using the term "signs" in the sense of "Unicode characters," we refer to such components as subsigns. In other words, subsigns are components with a Unicode identity. Traditionally, the classification of sinographs in dictionaries uses a number of several hundred signatures as radicals. Radicals are not discussed in this essay.

sections.heading: 2.3 Allographic Classes
sections.text: An important characteristic of components is that they can change their shape when combined with other components (for example, "i" becomes "i" when combined as in "i") Some of these variant forms were encoded in Unicode. Some sinographs can also have variant forms. Especially, during the Chinese writing reform [23], about 1753 sinographs received simplified forms (for example, "i" was encoded in Unicode) which are encoded separately in Unicode. Since these formal variations do not affect semantic or phonetic properties (at least not at the level of statistical language processing), we merge characters and their variants into groups called allographic classes.

sections.heading: 2.4 Semanticity and Phoneticity
sections.text: Subsigns can play a semantic role (if one of their meanings comes close to one of the meanings of the sinograph) and / or a phonetic role (if one of their readings is identical or in a particular language similar to one of the readings of the sinograph).In this essay we will deal with Mandarin and Japan.These two properties of subsigns with respect to signs can be quantified and are then called semantics and phonetics [24].

sections.heading: 5.1 Extracting Semantic Relations
sections.text: We tried three methods of estimating the semantics of signatures: 1. By measuring the distance between WordNet nodes using semantic measures of similarity, such as [37-39] or simply reversing the shortest path length in the WordNet diagram. This method was sterile. 2. By using the following algorithm: Whenever there was a semantic relationship (hyponymy, meronymy, antonymy, etc.) between two WordNet synsets, and we have a sinograph that belongs to a word from 2 and one of its signatures in a word from 1, we added a unit of "semantic weight" to the inclusion. We counted these across the three WordNets and obtained 6,816 allographic class inclusions of different weights.Here is an example: 114662574 (Mineral # 1).

sections.heading: 7 Unknown Character Semantic Approximation
sections.text: In addition to the usual NLP tasks, where a semantic relationship distance is required, our system can also be applied to processing unknown sinographs. Let's be an unknown sinograph (i.e., we know neither reading nor meaning), and its class. In our diagram, there is a Gu subgraph, which is generated by paths leading to u. As the graph is structured, our subgraph has no cycles. If we leave u and head for the sheets, there will be a first node ni for each path si, for which we have semantic annotations (e.g. a WordNet synset ID). In addition, we can weight the ni by using the product of semantic expectations (which are calculated similarly to phonetic expectations) of the edges of path uni and the distance from u on the path uni.We get a vector in the space of the WordNet synset IDs. This is not a precise semantic expectation, but LP can be used in different ways.

sections.heading: 8 Perspectives
sections.text: Other work focuses on three main areas: 1. the further analysis of the graph and the acquisition of knowledge of sinographic languages; 2. the processing of various higher graphs (n-grams, words, concepts,...) and the study of their interactions; 3. and last but not least, the manual validation of the semantics of the 39,719 class inclusions of our graph by a team of Chinese / Japanese native speakers within the framework of the HanziGraph project using the dedicated website http: / / www.hanzigraph.net.

metadata.abstractText: Chinese characters have a complex and hierarchical graphical structure carrying both semantic and phonetic information. We use this structure to enhance the text model and obtain better results in standard NLP operations. First of all, to tackle the problem of graphical variation we define allographic classes of characters. Next, the relation of inclusion of a subcharacter in a characters, provides us with a directed graph of allographic classes. We provide this graph with two weights: semanticity (semantic relation between subcharacter and character) and phoneticity (phonetic relation) and calculate “most semantic subcharacter paths” for each character. Finally, adding the information contained in these paths to unigrams we claim to increase the efficiency of text mining methods. We evaluate our method on a text classification task on two corpora (Chinese and Japanese) of a total of 18 million characters and get an improvement of 3% on an already high baseline of 89.6% precision, obtained by a linear SVM classifier. Other possible applications and perspectives of the system are discussed.
